Drivers of Editorial Decisions:

Private

Interest

Competition

Ads

Buzz

editor

relationship:

relationship:

relationship:

Correspondents have largely transactional relationships with editors—submitting stories from local context via email and receiving little feedback on why or why not a particular story is chosen.

As editorial pressures increasingly encroach on the newsroom, editors have less time and fewer incentives to foster personal one-on-one coaching to staffers.

Freelancers have develop pre-existing personal relationships with multiple editors to ensure their stories are seen and published.

Staffer

Freelancer

Local Correspondent

• Contracted by one media house and is paid a yearly salary for work.

• Usually a non-compete clause.

• Contracted by one media house and is paid per stories, with a two story guarantee per day.

• Allowed to pitch more than two stories with the possibility of earning more for each published story

• Pitches to multiple media outlets (between traditional, digital, international media)

• Deepen expertise in one specific subject area.

• Partnerships for recurring writing with traditional media or specialty, or csos

• Self-censorship, light reporting move along unnoticed.

• Held hostage by time deadlines and cannot put time towards longer more show-off stories stories

• Able to pick topics of interest. Time to research and report; but living a hustle lifestyle.

• Tight daily deadlines with little time to put towards longer features.
